titleStmt.title: The Ellesmere Manuscript of the Canterbury Tales

publicationStmt.publisher: Textual Communities and the Canterbury Tales Project, University of Saskatchewan

licence.p: All republication of all or any part of this transcript must credit its creators and all who have contributed to it, as listed in the sourceDesc element, and make available free-to-all any work derived from this resource under the same license.
Commercial republication is permitted, in accordance with these terms.

respStmt.name: F.J. Furnivall and the Chaucer Society
University of Michigan
respStmt.resp: 2000, capture as electronic text and SGML encoding

respStmt.name: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo, University of Saskatchewan

bibl.title: The Ellesmere Manuscript of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales
bibl.note: This text was originally captured in SGML by the University of Michigan (dated, 1 November 2000). We are grateful to Paul Schaffner for making these transcripts available to us, and for his assistance.

refsDecl.p: Encoded in 'P5' Text Encoding Initiative XML, optimized for input into the Textual Communities Project.

div.l: But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
And with that word / withouten moore respit
They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
And right anoon / withouten moore abood
His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
Ne take his ese / fully half a day
But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
So shyneth / in his white Baner large
That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
And by his Baner / born was his penoun
Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
Forth he rode with grete power and myght
Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
And by assaut he wan the Citee after
And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
But it weere al to long for to deuyse
But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
And with that word / withouten moore respit
They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte

Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke

As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued

Ne take his ese / fully half a day
But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle

And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte

And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
Forth he rode with grete power and myght
Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
And by assaut he wan the Citee after
And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
But it weere al to long for to deuyse
But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
And with that word / withouten moore respit
They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
And right anoon / withouten moore abood
His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
Ne take his ese / fully half a day
But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
So shyneth / in his white Baner large
That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
And by his Baner / born was his penoun
Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour

And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
Forth he rode with grete power and myght
Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
And by assaut he wan the Citee after
And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
But it weere al to long for to deuyse
But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
And with that word / withouten moore respit
They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
And right anoon / withouten moore abood
His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
Ne take his ese / fully half a day
But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
So shyneth / in his white Baner large
That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
And by his Baner / born was his penoun
Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
